generif.text: SMYD3 encodes a histone methyltransferase involved in the proliferation of cancer cells.
SMYD3-NY is a novel transcript variant of the SMYD3 gene, and SMYD3-NY protein may influence transcriptional regulation during spermatogenesis via HTMase activity
The common variable number of tandem repeats polymorphism in SMYD3 is a susceptibility factor for some types of human cancer.
Enhanced SMYD3 expression is associated with growth of breast cancer
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
study shows that SMYD3 polymorphism is not associated with the occurrence and metastasis of hepatocellular carcinoma in Chinese population
The proliferation, migration induction and apoptosis inhibition activities of SMYD3 in hepatocellular carcinoma may be mediated through RIZ1 CpG promoter hypermethylation.
A cleaved form lacking the amino-terminal 34 amino acids is higher in methyltransferase activity in cancer cells.
data indicate that the SMYD3 genotype is not related to the risk of developing NSCLC
Observational study of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)
VNTR polymorphism in the promoter region of SMYD3 gene may be a susceptibility factor for human cancers such as ESCC by interacting with tobacco carcinogens.
SMYD3 plays crucial roles in HeLa cell proliferation and migration/invasion, and that it may be a useful therapeutic target in human cervical carcinomas.
SMYD3 has a role in regulation of c-Met expression and in cell migration and invasion induced by HGF
HBx may induce the expression of histone methyltransferase SMYD3, which in turn stimulates cell proliferation and blocks apoptosis in HepG2 cells.
The results presented here identify SMYD3 as a new coactivator for estrogen receptor-mediated transcription, providing a possible link between SMYD3 overexpression and breast cancer.
Clinical trial of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)

presence of activating KRAS mutations is significantly correlated to an upregulation of 13 genes (adjusted P-value <0.05), among them DUSP4, a MAP-kinase phosphatase, and SMYD3, a histone methyltransferase
Down-regulation of SMYD3 induces G1-phase cell cycle arrest, indicating the potent induction of apoptosis by SMYD3 knockdown.
SmyD3 has a two-lobed structure with the substrate binding cleft located at the bottom of a 15-A-deep crevice formed between the N- and C-terminal lobes.

Structural analysis shows that the previously uncharacterized C-terminal domain of Smyd3 contains a tetratrico-peptide repeat domain which together with the SET and post-SET domains forms a deep, narrow substrate binding pocket.
HCVc could upregulate the methylation status of the RASSF1A promoter through regulation of SMYD3, and histone methylation may affect the DNA methylation of downstream gene by an unknown mechanism

The structure revealed an overall compact architecture in which the "split-SET" domain adopts a canonical SET domain fold and closely assembles with a Zn-binding MYND domain and a C-terminal superhelical 9 alpha-helical bundle.
Results show SMYD3 as an important new regulator of MMP-9 transcription, and provide a molecular link between SMYD3 overexpression and metastatic cancer progression.
Depletion of Smyd3 leads to diminished cell proliferation in HeLa cell line.
low miR-124 levels mediated by HCV core protein via DNMT1 promote intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma cell migration and invasion by targeting SMYD3
SMYD3 promotes prostate tumorigenesis and mediates epigenetic upregulation of AR expression.
Overexpression of SMYD3 promotes MRTF-A-mediated upregulation of MYL9 and migration of MCF-7 breast cancer cells
The expression profiling revealed in the more aggressive diseases (i.e. occurrence of metastases; persistent disease; disease-related death) a significant increase of EZH2 and SMYD3 gene expression.
methylation of MAP3K2 by SMYD3 increases MAP kinase signalling and promotes the formation of Ras-driven carcinomas

Results suggest that high expression of SMYD3 is related to the occurrence of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. Also, its suppression promoted the expression of RIZ1 suggesting a signal transduction pathway between SMYD3 and RIZ1.
Mutational analyses revealed that the MYND-domain of SMYD3 and domain III of hepatitis C virus NS5A are required for the interaction.
role of histone methyltransferase SMYD3 in tumors
SMYD3-mediated methylation of MAP3K2 increases mutant K-Ras-induced activation of ERK1/2. (Review)
High SMYD3 and pSTAT3 expressions may indicate poor prognosis of patients with gastric cancer
SMYD3 performed an important function in the aggressiveness of gastric carcinoma and may act as a promising target for prognostic prediction.
SMYD3 and MMP-9 may play important roles in tumor invasion, metastasis, and prognosis and could work as promising targets for prognostic prediction in gastric cancer.
represent the proof of principle that SMYD3 is a druggable target

Loss of SMYD3-HSP90 interaction leads to SMYD3 mislocalization within the nucleus, thereby losing its chromatin association. This results in reduction of SMYD3-mediated cell proliferation and, potentially, impairment of SMYD3's oncogenic activity.
Results support a proto-oncogenic role for SMYD3 in prostate carcinogenesis, mainly due to its methyltransferase enzymatic activity.

SET and MYND domain-containing protein 3 expression and TGF-beta1 expression in gastric cancer (GC) tissues were significantly and positively correlated. High expression levels of SMYD3 and TGF-beta1 can indicate poor prognoses for GC patients.
Results showed that SMYD3 is overexpressed in human glioma and contributes to glioma tumorigenicity through p53.
SMYD3 interacts with the human positive coactivator 4 (PC4) and that such interaction potentiates a group of genes whose expression is linked to cell proliferation and invasion.
A novel HBx-interacting protein, SMYD3, was identified, leading to proposal of a novel mechanism of AP-1 activation in HBV-infected cells.

SMYD3 physically interacts with the promoter of BCLAF1 and upregulates its expression by accumulating di- and trimethylation of H3K4 at the BCLAF1 locus.  SMYD3 overexpression in bladder cancer cells promotes autophagy activation.
High expression of SMYD3 is associated with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
results clearly revealed structural determinants for the substrate preference of SMYD3 and provided mechanistic insights into lysine methylation of MAP3K2.
SMYD3 enhances tumorigenicity in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma by enhancing transcription of ezrin and LOXL2, which are involved in proliferation, migration, and invasion.

The present results suggest that NS5A interacts with SMYD3 and induces AP-1 activation, possibly by facilitating binding between HSP90 and SMYD3. This may be a novel mechanism of AP-1 activation in HCV-infected cells.
Postulate that AdoMet cofactor acts like a key and locks Smyd3 in a closed conformation.

However, stratification of patients according to their smoking history significantly expands the prognostic value of SMYD3 to overall survival and other features, suggesting that smoking-related effects saturate the clinical analysis and mask the function of SMYD3 as an oncogenic potentiato
SMYD3-mediated H2A.Z.1K101 dimethylation activates cyclin A1 expression and contributes to driving the proliferation of breast cancer cells.
SMYD3-mediated methylation of AKT1 at lysine 14 is essential for AKT1 activation and that SMYD3-mediated AKT1 methylation appears to be a good target for development of anti-cancer therapy.

Substrate crevices of Smyd2 and Smyd3 show distinct features in terms of spatial, hydration, and electrostatic properties that emphasize their characteristic modes of substrates interaction and entry pathways for inhibitor binding.
VNTR genotype 3/3 of the SMYD3 gene was associated with the risk of ovarian cancer.

The property that SMYD3 is preferentially recruited to individual promoters may rely on both its binding sequences and its binding partners. Further investigation is required to clarify this specificity.

SMYD3-mediated methylation of HER2 at Lysine 175 may regulate the formation of HER2 homodimer and subsequent autophosphorylation and suggest that the SMYD3-mediated methylation pathway seems to be a good target for development of novel anti-cancer therapy.

EZH2 rs12670401 and rs6464926 polymorphisms, EZH2 and SMYD3 expression, clinical staging, lymph node metastasis, human epidermal growth factor receptor-2 (HER2) status, and metastasis may be correlated with breast cancer susceptibility and prognosis.
High Ki67, EZH2, and SMYD3 immunoexpression, adjusted for standard clinicopathological parameters, independently predicts outcome in patients with prostate cancer, at diagnosis.
Overexpression of SMYD3 is an independent prognostic risk of unfavorable prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The anti-SMYD3 therapy may be a potential approach to treat HCC.

Findings suggest that antisense lncRNA EZR-AS1, as a member of an RNA polymerase complex and through enhanced SMYD3-dependent H3K4 methylation, plays an important role in enhancing transcription of the EZR gene to promote the mobility and invasiveness of human cancer cells.
SMYD3 VNTR 3/3 polymorphism confers an increased risk and poor prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma in a Chinese population

Study uncovers that SMYD3 controls Wnt induced activation of ASCL2 in cancer stem cells (CSCs) by regulating H3K4me3 status. These findings suggest that Wnt signals through a SMYD3-mediated epigenetic switch to promote ASCL2 expression and CSC maintenance in human gastric carcinoma (GC). Overexpression of SMYD3 and ASCL2 are associated with poor prognosis in GC patients.

We show that tool compounds as well as CRISPR/Cas9 fail to reproduce many of the cell proliferation findings associated with SMYD2 and SMYD3 inhibition previously obtained with RNAi based approaches and with early stage chemical probes.
Study reported for the first time that SMYD3 promoter hypomethylation was associated with colorectal cancer in a Chinese cohort.

our data point at SMYD3 as a pivotal SMAD3 cofactor that promotes TGFbeta-dependent mesenchymal gene expression and cell migration in breast cancer, and support SMYD3 as a promising pharmacological target for anti-cancer therapy.
we identified ANKHD1 as a co-regulator with SMYD3. We provided evidence that SMYD3 transactivates its target genes and promotes HCC cells migration and invasion through ANKHD1.

SMYD3 overexpression promotes the tumorigenicity and intrahepatic metastasis of Hepatocellular carcinoma cell via upregulation of CDK2 and MMP2, but also suggest SMYD3 could be a practical prognosis marker or therapeutic target against the disease.
our results define the important role of SMYD3 in the metastasis process of epithelial ovarian cancer
STAT3-mediated transcription of SMYD3 plays a role in promoting the progression of chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Robust protocols for production, handling, and crystallization of SMYD3 and biophysical and biochemical assays for clarification of SMYD3 biochemistry and identification of useful lead compounds.
The overexpression of SMYD3 promoted proliferation, migration, and invasion of pancreatic cancer, and SMYD3 may affect the pancreatic cancer progression by regulating MMP-2 rather than caspase-3.

Study of ovarian cancer (OC) cells grown in 3D and 2D culture revealed that SMYD3 expression was elevated in OC spheroids in association with increased H3K4 methylation. SMYD3 and H3K4me3 binding at the ITGB6 and ITGAM promoters was increased in spheroids compared to that in monolayer cells suggesting that the SMYD3-H3K4me3-integrin pathway plays a crucial role in OC metastasis to the peritoneal surface.
These results revealed that SMYD3 was a novel host factor recruited by NP to supporting Ebola virus mRNA transcription through increasing the binding of VP30 to NP.
The SMYD3 methyltransferase promotes myogenesis by activating the myogenin regulatory network.
Variable number tandem repeat polymorphism in SMYD3 gene is associated with breast cancer.
High expression of SMYD3 indicates poor survival outcome and promotes tumour progression through an IGF-1R/AKT/E2F-1 positive feedback loop in bladder cancer.
Upregulation of SMYD3 and SMYD3 VNTR 3/3 polymorphism increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.
VHL-HIF-2alpha axis-induced SMYD3 upregulation drives renal cell carcinoma progression via direct trans-activation of EGFR.
Long Noncoding RNA EZR-AS1 Regulates the Proliferation, Migration, and Apoptosis of Human Venous Endothelial Cells via SMYD3.
SMYD3 overexpression indicates poor prognosis and promotes cell proliferation, migration and invasion in nonsmall cell lung cancer.
Histone methyltransferase Smyd3 is a new regulator for vascular senescence.
SMYD3: a regulator of epigenetic and signaling pathways in cancer.
Mechanism of the Conformational Change of the Protein Methyltransferase SMYD3: A Molecular Dynamics Simulation Study.
SMYD3 promotes hepatocellular carcinoma progression by methylating S1PR1 promoters.
Novel insights into SMYD2 and SMYD3 inhibitors: from potential anti-tumoural therapy to a variety of new applications.
Elevated placental histone H3K4 methylation via upregulated histone methyltransferases SETD1A and SMYD3 in preeclampsia and its possible involvement in hypoxia-induced pathophysiological process.
SMYD3 Impedes Small Cell Lung Cancer Sensitivity to Alkylation Damage through RNF113A Methylation-Phosphorylation Cross-talk.
SMYD3 promotes aerobic glycolysis in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma via H3K4me3-mediated PKM2 transcription.
SMYD3 regulates gastric cancer progression and macrophage polarization through EZH2 methylation.
SMYD3 regulates the abnormal proliferation of non-small-cell lung cancer cells via the H3K4me3/ANO1 axis.
SMYD3 associates with the NuRD (MTA1/2) complex to regulate transcription and promote proliferation and invasiveness in hepatocellular carcinoma cells.
Histone lysine methyltransferase SMYD3 promotes oral squamous cell carcinoma tumorigenesis via H3K4me3-mediated HMGA2 transcription.
SMYD3 represses tumor-intrinsic interferon response in HPV-negative squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck.
The SMYD3-dependent H3K4me3 status of IGF2 intensifies local Th2 differentiation in CRSwNP via positive feedback.
SMYD3: a new regulator of adipocyte precursor proliferation at the early steps of differentiation.
THAP3 recruits SMYD3 to OXPHOS genes and epigenetically promotes mitochondrial respiration in hepatocellular carcinoma.

BP.term: positive regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II

MF.term: RNA polymerase II cis-regulatory region sequence-specific DNA binding
RNA polymerase II intronic transcription regulatory region sequence-specific DNA binding

name: SET and MYND domain containing 3
other_names: zinc finger protein, subfamily 3A (MYND domain containing), 1
summary: This gene encodes a histone methyltransferase which functions in RNA polymerase II complexes by an interaction with a specific RNA helicase. Multiple transcript variants encoding different isoforms have been found for this gene. [provided by RefSeq, Dec 2011].
